author: @mochalily3735
text: To co-sign what Olay said about Bahamians having a culture vulture conversation about Drake, many Jamaicans have the same conversations about him. There are quite a few artists who love to come to our island and love to use our patois and accent in their music‚Ä¶ but they typically give something in return. They big up the island, they feature our artists, they boost tourism and put money into the country. They also come back multiple times and just enjoy the culture regardless of if they keep using our style in their new projects. Drake is not one of those artists. As much as I don‚Äôt necessarily like DJ Khalid‚Ä¶ that mf has repeatedly praised our island and shows the beauty of it in every post and every interview when he‚Äôs here. He spends time and money on the island and promotes our artists. Drake is just a vulture who does nothing but a cheap Jafakean accent. Appropriation vs appreciation.

author: @ShanuWral

author: @goreyfantod5213
text:
That dude Tahoe was not really listening - he has his narrative & he just kept repeating it.

Side, but related, note: I have a VERY similar background to Drake 
- White Canadian mother + Black American father. 
- Raised by single-parent mother in Canada, father not present (at all, in my case). 
- Limited access to Black culture & what access we had was through music, movies, tv & immigrants from predominantly Black  but not American communities (the Caribbean, assorted African countries, etc.).

Most of what Tahoe (?) was saying about Drake's upbringing & perspective was incorrect - a mix of Drake's made-up narrative about his childhood & his speculation as a Black American about what it must have been like for Drake. Without typing out an essay about it, I'll just say this: Drake, me, all of us multicultural people who grew up in unique circumstances (isolated in majority-white, deeply segregated, racist colonial Canada), had access to choices that other Black people do not. Simple as that. 

One obvious example that's not too deep: I have dual citizenship & was able to choose which country to live in as an adult. 
One less obvious example that is super deep: I chose to seek out Black culture and, in that process, found that I empathise & ally myself with al  oppressed people & our cultures rather than with the dominant White culture (such as it is). To wit: set aside the questions about how Black Drake is - has Drake expressed support, or any opinion at all, for First Nations & Metis people in Canada?

text:
Beyonce is a false equivalence. She grew up around house because of her Uncle Johnny (that was literally the point of the album). She also has always proudly been Southern. People used to make fun of her country accent all the time.

replies.author: @morwaze
replies.text:
The truth is that in today's day and age... black kids with 2 black parents are raised in rich suburban communities not knowing shit about struggle. Growing up in majority white bubbles where the only black people they see are the black people they come home to. 

Many of them don't feel or fit in with the hood and experience blackness from a much more "comfortable" tier than a lot of blacks. 

What makes them any less of a culture vulture than Drake? They can only relate to hip hop in as much as they're skin colors are similar. 

Im only asking this to make the point that for every person claiming to be part of rap culture there's someone saying they're not black enough to be welcome. 

Is drake corny? Hell yes. Is he outta pocket for frontin like he gang? Yes. 

But if drake is a CV its a whole LOT of CVs... and i wont even get into how toxic rap culture is

replies.author: @leavecowsalone
replies.text: @Cdr2002 this is what I have been thinking, too. People like T.I. and later on Young Thug brought on waves of a very specific ATL sound during their heights, respectively. I would say both of them ‚Äúbroke waves‚Äù for their contemporaries and made room for young dro, shawty lo, rocko after T.I. blew up and the migos, future (preceded young thug kind of, but his kind of modern trap blew up post barter 6, even though it was an unrelated project bc similar veins) had room to blow up after young thug. Now, regardless of era, if you understand hip hop, you know the ATL sound when you hear it. Drake could have done that FOR TORONTO, for his specific style and accent, for his social conditioning. Instead, Drake runs to any region where there are black people and steals the culture for a single or two, rinse and repeat. He‚Äôs been atl, he‚Äôs been west coast, he‚Äôs been carrib, he‚Äôs gone afrobeats, he‚Äôs tried to be afrolatino, and he‚Äôs flown across the Atlantic to do the UK hip hop style. He will do anything besides use his own personality. Why? I don‚Äôt know. It rubs me the wrong way.

replies.author: @Cdr2002
replies.text:
@leavecowsalone you said a mouthful and I mean that as a full compliment. Honestly you thought about this way deeper than me and there‚Äôs a lot of good content in your reply. 

I think Drake does this out of a combination of two factors: 

1. Simple trend chasing business movies. 

2. Insecurity. Despite what some racist mfers will say about biracial folk, Drake is ten times blacker than someone like Vanilla Ice, but has that same kind of culture envy of wanting to be seen as hard and gangsta and be accepted by the culture that exists instead of creating a new facet of the hip hop culture that could lift up people like him who‚Äôve had experiences like his.

replies.author: @Cdr2002
replies.text: @leavecowsalone one more point I wanted to make: Drake is basically like if someone made an entire career out of the vibe of Will Smith‚Äôs ‚ÄúLost and Found‚Äù

author: @ChandawilaArts
text:
As an African who is considered black racially, drake has BEEEEEN a problem this side the moment he started using Afrobeats and African artists in his music without actually the cultures they came from or the peers and African artists who‚Äôve been doing this for so long. With the example of one dance. That song is like diluted juice that you drink because you‚Äôre thirsty not because it‚Äôs actually good. Drake is very smart predicting trends and he will never have that credibility taken away when all we hear on the radio is him. However one dance could have been an artful masterpiece considering who he collaborated with Wizkid has been an incredibly unique voice in the Afrobeats with such a distinct sound and very cool incorporations of his Yoruba culture and his youthful style and Lagos city life. Like if we put drakes one dance and compare it to wizkid‚Äôs solo‚Äôs you would see the missed artistry that could have been so unique and even revolutionary in terms of dictating the afrobeats wave that followed. I‚Äôm a young adult of the 2000‚Äôs and I say this knowing they are many drake songs in my older playlists that I played so much. I mean some of my favourite songs of all time have drake in it: jungle, Hold on,blem‚Ä¶.. 
These didn‚Äôt just peak my interest because it was drake but because they felt like they were made in a way that wasn‚Äôt stereotypical to the times of music where tyga and ty dolla sign were making music that felt so disconnected to my young self. But now I‚Äôm almost 25 and drake is still doing the same thing‚Ä¶.. and to me that does not prove that someone should be a goat or king of rap

author: @Magnumweight
text: Since this is about music, let it not go unsaid that the Olay and Friends theme is fantastic

author: @amelakn
text: You can‚Äôt love the culture but disregard the people who created it and try to alienate that culture from the politics (resisting  and rejecting anti-blackness and white supremacism) at the heart of that culture. The history of Black people being alienated from their own cultural production, is a long one that we have seen repeated with rock ‚Äòn‚Äô roll, jazz, and blues. Drake‚Äôs hip hop career overall has demonstrated this type of alienation. However, in fairness, it has not only been Drake who is done so as I can look to many others. I think what‚Äôs different is that unfortunately, Drake has become the poster child for this process because of the fact that he‚Äôs the most successful monetarily.  With regard to what‚Äôs happening right now, I‚Äôm on team Kendrick.

author: @hopesdaughter5947
text: ‚úäüèΩüñ§üéôÔ∏è As a 51 year old BW who was born and raised in the New York City borough of Southeast Queens,a former performance poet, and used to work for the original Shirt Kings, attended high school with the Deceptions, Smith & Wesson, Craig G and Maxwell, the R&B Brooklyn singer, and have other hip-hop connections... I wish I could be on this panel. Phew. But happy you hit the most vital part... he is another aspect of the "manosphere" and he is a "vulture" presenting nothing but 'changing masks' right in front of everyone's face. He's already been put out for wearing black face. Hard stop. I'll add, women need to respect themselves more and stop listening to his women-devaluing music. He literally colonized Atlanta rappers. I could write a dissertation on Drake. He's like a covert narc to Future's overt malignant personality. Like my ex-husband, covert. ü§¢ He's been moving through psychological levels of supremacy and paternalism, just like the oppressors of the past, the core of narcissism. Respect. ‚òÆÔ∏è

author: @dthomscappello
text: When you guys rightfully pointed out that Drake didn't grow up and he keeps courting the demo identity of a young "manosphere boy" perspective, I wondered if this is part of a bigger aspect of capitalist entertainment industry: always pushing a young person's pov in the art and content (literally hooking customers young like happy meals). Not to say Drake isn't responsible for himself, but is his success reflective of an infantilism that's part of commercial music, in general?

replies.author: @autumnstaten5120
replies.text: I agree with this 100%üëèüèΩüëèüèΩüëèüèΩ

replies.author: @PanderingSlats
replies.text:
Yes, and it's 100% a capitalist *entertainment* thing, well beyond music. A lot of storytelling focuses around adolescence and it's not just for hooking young consumers; by idealizing teenage years, older fans remain attached like they're reliving their glory years.
What truly sets the nail in Drake's coffin for the manosphere boy motif is how he keeps flying that flag despite showing capability in adapting/reinventing himself. It's like if Will Smith spent his whole acting career playing roles like Independence Day or Men In Black: sooner or later, you're too old to play the rookie.

replies.author: @kobaltkween
replies.text:
I also think that it's kinda literally ignorant.  I live here in Texas where some people line dance on the weekends.  Line dancing comes at least half from African Americans.  There is a pop/dance lane to country, and it's a part of black Texan culture.  Before she came out with her album, there were TikToks of black girls in cowboy hats out at bars line dancing and showing off their skills.  

Beyonc√©'s lane as a Houston black girl includes all the genres they mention, especially as she's presented them.

replies.author: @jah-oshun
replies.text: Nahhh at the risk of sounding like my brother Tahoe, we really gotta stop the revisionist history when it comes to Drake. Take Care & Nothing Was the Same are absolutely two classics, and so are his mixtapes. And that‚Äôs because he was doing what people keep tryna insist he never did, which is paying proper respects to his Houston Atlanta Bay Area & r&b influences and showing he was a student of both games while doing his own thing. I think it‚Äôs very valid to hate what he‚Äôs become but stop tryna gaslight me into thinking we all never fucked with Drake dammit !!!!!!

author: @EricKoonitsky-bd3hl
text: I'm grateful for the discussion of the parallels between Nas vs. Jay-Z and Kendrick vs. Drake. I had the same feeling FD described, waving the victory flag because Nas expertly delivered all the criticisms I and others had been making toward "the Jigga man". And like the Drake defenders, people championing Jay-Z resorted to bad faith criticisms of the homophobia that Nas (like Jay-Z and pretty much every rapper at that time) engaged in while delivering his valid critique. That and "but that Takeover beat!" and "Jay-Z has $100 million! He's bigger than rap!" just solidified Nas's criticism and victory. For me, at least.

author: @ageneralist.
text:
I get the Beyonc√© comparison but  Beyonc√© is tapping into genres that she has a tangible connection to or that she has an established reason for representing. 

Not being a Stan here but this 3 part saga she is on is to reclaim black music for its originators. She always includes notable figures in these projects to bring light to their contributions.

Past that, she grew up in Texas, so has a foundational link to country. Her uncle Jonny, a gay man, helped raise her and expose her to house music. As a black American she has a birthright to R&B. When she did ‚ÄúThe Gift‚Äù it was because she was on the cast of a film set in Africa and she was tasked with doing an OST representing the film (which again, she sourced artists of the culture to take part in).

I don‚Äôt feel like the comparison is the same because it feels like there is always a connection or legitimate reason other than ‚ÄúI just like the way this sounds and I feel like I can make some money off of popularising this sound.‚Äù 

But I‚Äôm not the most familiar with Drake‚Äôs discography or history within different genres so I‚Äôm happy to be proven wrong.

author: @ishan5011
text: Hip Hop and rap was never about the culture and aesthetics presented in 90s rap and gangster rap, though the technicality was developing. It was about Mcing, proving who's the best and having fun. I think this battle is a return to form, by entertaining crowds and moving opinions. It's so big and come so far now its like the best of both worlds.

replies.author: @blackflagsnroses6013
replies.text: From what I understand Hip Hop is a urban subculture produced from community block parties where DJs would bring their turntables and mess around with the music, followed by MCs to living up the crowd and hype up the DJ. Followed by breakdancing and graffiti art work, it‚Äôs basically the cultural expression of street arts which became voice of a generation of the urban black American experience. From Rapper‚Äôs Delight and The Message you get that Hip Hop culture is both fun partying and real messaging about a social experience which evolved into that 90s aesthetics of pushing the boundaries into gangsta rap following the success and popularity of gangster films in Hollywood

replies.author: @seanthornton726
replies.text: @blackflagsnroses6013¬† Hop Hop started with the Bboy and Bgirl. Cool Herc created the Marry Go Round technique to isolate the breaks of the song specifically for the Bboys and Bgirls to go off. Herc's call was, " Bboys, are you ready?"  The music in the beginning was centered around the art of Dance. The art of MCing developed soon after. The art of graffiti pre dates the music. It became part of the culture of HipHop later.. The 90s saw the infrotration of corporate actors.

replies.author: @cardi5
replies.text: From Philly over here‚Ä¶hip hop IS a lived experience and rapping, dancing, graffiti is how the experience IS expressed. The looks from the late 70s, 80s, 90s are shaped by the lived experience of those apart of the culture. Some were partying in all eras, some were in them streets and some were doing both. In 86 the first gangsta rap song was PSK by Schoolly D who is from Philly around the same time that DJ Jazzy Jeff and The Fresh Prince came out with Girls of the world ain‚Äôt nothing but trouble. The artistry with MCing or Microphone Command was being able to grab the attention of the audience and get them to follow your commands and then rapping was the artistry of being a wordsmith and keeping the crowds attention and being able to battle and defend yourself against any challengers. Hip hop lost its artistry when the business end allowed ghostwriters to pump fake for the artists‚Ä¶‚Ä¶Kendrick putting these diss tracks out as fast as he is and being consistently clear on theme of what his diss is about is highlighting the art of rapping. I imagine Drake in a room full of ghostwriters trying to get his comeback right which may account for his sh*t sounding like it‚Äôs all over the place.

replies.author: @ishan5011
replies.text: @cardi5 I agree. Yes to the experience, graf, dancing and rapping. It's all filtered through the generations lens through the decades. I think this exchange in the genre's current iteration has attracted a lot of people into discourse about what is 'real' and comparing it to past eras moreso than usual. All I'm saying is in this competition of people in MC roles, this is core hip-hop and I'm glad to see that aspect alive in 2024. I think it's larger role in this day socially, culturally is really fascinating. I can see the influence of hip-hop's competitive and truth telling history in it. It's nice, that's why people are so excited.
